skills.name: Recognise and use the law of distributivity
Mental multiplication and the laws of arithmetic

explanations.A: If you try this with numbers it may be easier to see. For example: 6 √ó 3 = 3 √ó 6 = 18, so that works. 6 √∑ 3 = 2 but 3 √∑ 6 = ¬Ω, so numbers have to be in the correct position for division.
explanations.B: I think that you have not recognised that division is non-commutative, which means we cannot switch the ùëé and ùëè around.
explanations.C: I think that you have not recognised that division is non-commutative, which means we cannot switch the ùëé and ùëè around.
explanations.D: I think that you have not recognised that division is non-commutative, which means we cannot switch the ùëé and ùëè around, but multiplication is commutative.

explanations.A: If you try this with numbers it may be easier to see. For example: 6 Ôºã 1 = 1 Ôºã 6 = 7, so that works. 6 ‚àí 1 = 5 but 1 ‚àí 6 = ‚àí5, so numbers have to be in the correct position for subtraction.
explanations.B: I think that you have not recognised that subtraction is non-commutative, which means we cannot switch the ùëé and ùëè around.
explanations.C: I think that you have not recognised that subtraction is non-commutative, which means we cannot switch the ùëé and ùëè around.
explanations.D: I think that you have not recognised that subtraction is non-commutative, which means we cannot switch the ùëé and ùëè around, but addition is commutative.

explanations.A: The law of commutativity says you can swap numbers around and still get the same answer. This law applies when you multiply.
explanations.B: I think that you may be confused with factor pairs.
explanations.C: I think that you may be confusing associativity and commutativity.
explanations.D: I think that you may be confusing distributivity and commutativity.

explanations.A: I think that you may be confusing associativity and commutativity.
explanations.B: The law of commutativity says you can swap numbers around and still get the same answer. This law applies when you add.
explanations.C: I think that you may be confusing distributivity and commutativity.
explanations.D: I think that you may be confused with factor pairs.

explanations.A: 25 ‚úï 14 = 25 ‚úï (2 ‚úï ‚òÖ). The 25 appears on both sides. The 14 is now represented as 2 ‚úï ‚òÖ. Therefore, we know that 14 = 2 ‚úï ‚òÖ which means that ‚òÖ must have a value of 7.
explanations.B: I think you might have missed the '2 ‚úï' in the brackets.
explanations.C: I think you might have used subtraction instead of division when solving 14 = 2 ‚úï ‚òÖ.
explanations.D: I think you might have used multiplication instead of division when solving 14 = 2 ‚úï ‚òÖ

explanations.A: I think you might have used subtraction instead of division when solving 12 = 4 ‚úï ‚òÖ.
explanations.B: I think you might have missed the '4 ‚úï' in the brackets.
explanations.C: 15 ‚úï 12 = 15 ‚úï (4 ‚úï ‚òÖ). The 15 appears on both sides. The 12 is now represented as 4 ‚úï ‚òÖ. Therefore, we know that 12 = 4 ‚úï ‚òÖ which means that ‚òÖ must have a value of 3.
explanations.D: I think you might have solved this step incorrectly: 12 = 4 ‚úï ‚òÖ.

explanations.A: Not quite. Commutativity describes how, in addition and multiplication, you can swap the numbers around and still get the same answer. For example: 7 ‚úï 9 = 9 ‚úï 7.
explanations.B: Not quite. 5 and 2 are not factors of 7, 5 ‚úï 2 = 10 NOT 7
explanations.C: Not quite. Associativity describes how, in addition and multiplication, you can change the order in which you choose to add or multiply. For example: (7 x 3) x 3 = 7 x (3 x 3)
explanations.D: Distributivity describes how multiplying a group of numbers added together is the same as multiplying the numbers separately before finding the sum. For example 7 lots of 9 is the same as adding 5 lots of 9 to 2 lots of 9. As shown here.

explanations.A: Not quite. Associativity describes how, in addition and multiplication, you can change the order of which you choose to add or multiply. For example: (8 x 2) x 4 = 8 x (2 x 4)
explanations.B: Not quite. Commutativity describes how, in addition and multiplication, you can swap the numbers around and still get the same answer. For example: 8 ‚úï 4 = 4 ‚úï 8.
explanations.C: Distributivity describes how multiplying a group of numbers added together is the same as multiplying the numbers separately before finding the sum. For example 8 lots of 4 is the same as adding 5 lots of 4 to 3 lots of 4. As shown here.
explanations.D: Not quite. 5 and 3 are not factors of 8, 5 ‚úï 3 = 15 NOT 8

explanations.A: Almost, just don't forget to take into account the place value of the 4. It's not worth 4 as it isn't in the units column
explanations.B: Almost, just make sure you are multiplying and adding in the correct places.
explanations.C: Almost. Just check the totals here
explanations.D: We multiply the tens by 3, then the units by 3, and then add the totals together.

explanations.A: We multiply the tens by 3, then the units by 3, and then add the totals together.
explanations.B: Almost, just make sure you are multiplying and adding in the correct places.
explanations.C: Almost. Just check the totals here
explanations.D: Almost, just don't forget to take into account the place value of the 5. It's not worth 5 as it isn't in the units column
